name: 2,2,6,6,9a-pentamethyl-12-methylidene-13-oxodecahydro-4H-3b,11a-ethanophenanthro[1,2-d][1,3]dioxole-4,9,10(3aH)-triyl triacetate
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1590
Reason: The compound 2,2,6,6,9a-pentamethyl-12-methylidene-13-oxodecahydro-4H-3b,11a-ethanophenanthro[1,2-d][1,3]dioxole-4,9,10(3aH)-triyl triacetate has a high melting point due to its complex molecular structure. The presence of a methylidene group, which is a rigid and planar structure, tends to increase the melting point, estimated to be around +30°C. The methyl groups, which are bulky and increase the molecular weight, contribute to the steric hindrance and raise the melting point, estimated to be around +20°C. The aromatic ring, which is a planar and rigid structure, tends to increase the melting point, estimated to be around +40°C. The triyl group, which is a bulky and planar structure, tends to increase the melting point, estimated to be around +30°C. The acetate group, which is a polar and flexible group, tends to lower the melting point, estimated to be around -20°C. Summing these contributions, the predicted increase over the base value of phenol would be +30°C (methylidene group) + +20°C (methyl groups) + +40°C (aromatic ring) + +30°C (triyl group) -20°C (acetate group), amounting to a +100°C increase.
